sen.j: 二条 定高（にじょう さだたか、建久元年（1190年）－暦仁元年1月22日 (旧暦)（1238年2月8日））は、鎌倉時代前期の公卿。
sen.e: Sadataka NIJO (1190 - February 15, 1238) was a Kugyo (a high court noble) during the early Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: 没年をグレゴリオ暦に変更しました。
sen.e: Sadataka NIJO (1190 - February 15, 1238) was a kugyo (a high court noble) during the early Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: 公卿の訳が大文字になっていましたので修正しました。
sen.e: Sadataka NIJO (1190 - February 15, 1238) was a kugyo (a high court noble) during the early Kamakura period.
He was a son of Sangi (Councilor) Mitsunaga KUJO.
sen.cmt: C列に イギリス式綴りの "councillor" とアメリカ式綴りの "Councilor" がありました。指示書に従い、アメリカ式綴りを採用しました。
sen.e: He was a son of sangi (Councilor) Mitsunaga KUJO.
sen.cmt: 参議の訳が大文字になっていましたので修正しました。
sen.e: He was a son of sangi (Councilor) Mitsunaga KUJO.

sen.j: 兄・参議海住山長房の猶子。
sen.e: He was adopted by his older brother, Sangi Nagafusa KAIJUSEN.
sen.cmt: 「海住山」「長房」それぞれの一般的な読みの組み合わせとしました。
sen.e: He was adopted by his older brother, sangi Nagafusa KAIJUSEN.
sen.cmt: 参議の訳が大文字になっていましたので修正しました。
sen.e: He was adopted by his older brother, sangi Nagafusa KAIJUSEN.

sen.j: 勧修寺流九条家 (勧修寺流)の出身であるが、二条東洞院に邸宅を有していたため、「二条」と称される。
sen.e: Although Sadataka was from the Kanjuji faction of Kujo family, he was called "Nijo", because he lived in a residence located at Nijo Higashinotoin.
sen.cmt: 「勧修寺流」の「流」を 29534_足利義稙.xls の例にならって"faction" としました。「(勧修寺流)」は完全に重複してしまいますので、訳文では一回しか訳出していません。外国文献では "branch" としている例もありました。「二条」は"Nijo"に統一しています。
sen.e: Although Sadataka was from the Kanjuji faction of Kujo family, he was called "Nijo", because he lived in a residence located at Nijo Higashinotoin.
Although Sadataka was from the Kanjuji faction of Kujo family, he was called "Nijo", because he lived in a residence located at Nijo Higashinotoin.
His name was originally Tamesada, and was later changed to Tsunemitsu.
sen.cmt: 「経光」は一般的な読みとしました。
sen.e: His name was originally Tamesada, and was later changed to Tsunemitsu.
His name was originally Tamesada, and was later changed to Tsunemitsu.

sen.j: 建久9年（1198年）に六位蔵人となり、同年従五位下に叙される。
sen.e: In 1198, he was appointed Rokui-Kurodo (Chaimberlain of Sixth Rank), and Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) the same year.
sen.cmt: 蔵人頭 "Head Chamberlain"が後方に出現しますので、蔵人を"Chaimberlain" としました。
sen.e: In 1198, he was appointed to Rokui-Kurodo (Chaimberlain of Sixth Rank), and bestowed Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) in the same year.
sen.cmt: appointedにtoを加えました。叙されるの訳が欠けていましたので加えました。
sen.e: In 1198, he was appointed to Rokui-Kurodo (Chaimberlain of Sixth Rank), and bestowed Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) in the same year.

sen.j: 以後、諸国の国司を歴任。
sen.e: He was then appointed to kokushi (provincial governor) in various provinces.
He was successively appointed to kokushi (provincial governor) in various provinces.
sen.cmt: 歴任の意味を加えました。
sen.e: He was successively appointed to kokushi (provincial governor) in various provinces.

sen.j: 承元3年（1209年）、兄・長房の参議辞任による譲りを受けて右少弁に抜擢される。
sen.e: In 1209, his older brother resigned from the position of Sangi to let Sadataka take it over, and he was promoted to Ushoben (Minor Controller of the Right).
In 1209, his older brother resigned from the position of sangi to let Sadataka take it over, and he was promoted to Ushoben (Minor Controller of the Right).
sen.cmt: 参議の訳が大文字になっていましたので修正しました。
sen.e: In 1209, his older brother resigned from the position of sangi to let Sadataka take it over, and he was promoted to Ushoben (Minor Controller of the Right).

sen.j: 建保2年（1214年）に右大弁兼蔵人頭となり、安房国を知行国として与えられる。
sen.e: In 1214, he became Udaiben (Major Controller of the Right) and acting Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain), with Awa Province given as his provincial fiefdom (chigyo-koku).
In 1214, he became Udaiben (Major Controller of the Right) and acted as Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain), with Awa Province given as his provincial fiefdom (chigyo-koku).
sen.cmt: acting Kurodo--を、acting as Kurodo--としました。
sen.e: In 1214, he became Udaiben (Major Controller of the Right) and acted as Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain), with Awa Province given as his provincial fiefdom (chigyo-koku).

sen.j: 建保6年（1218年）には参議に任じられ、承久元年（1219年）に従三位に叙され、翌承久2年（1220年）に権中納言に昇る。
sen.e: He was appointed Sangi in 1218, awarded Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) in 1219, and promoted to Gon Chunagon (Provisional Middle Counselor) the following year, in 1220.
sen.cmt: 翌年+年の訳は冗長に思えますが、意図的に残してあります。
sen.e: He was appointed to sangi in 1218, awarded Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) in 1219, and promoted to Gon Chunagon (Provisional Middle Counselor) the following year, in 1220.
sen.cmt: 参議の訳が大文字になっていましたので修正しました。
sen.e: He was appointed to sangi in 1218, awarded Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) in 1219, and promoted to Gon Chunagon (Provisional Middle Counselor) the following year, in 1220.

sen.j: 葉室宗行から従四位下を譲られる程、親しかったが、承久の乱においては定高は兄・長房とともに後鳥羽上皇の挙兵に反対する立場に回り、宗行と運命を分けた。
sen.e: Sadataka was in so deep acquaintance with Muneyuki HAMURO that Muneyuki granted his position of Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) to Sadataka, but the two parted ways as Sadataka, together with his older brother Nagafusa, opposed to the Retired Emperor Gotoba raising an army in the occasion of Jokyu War.

Sadataka was in so deep acquaintance with Muneyuki HAMURO that Muneyuki granted his position of Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) to Sadataka, but the two parted ways as Sadataka, together with his older brother Nagafusa, opposed to the Retired Emperor Gotoba raising an army in the occasion of Jokyu War.

Sadataka was in so deep acquaintance with Muneyuki HAMURO that Muneyuki granted his position of Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) to Sadataka, but the two parted ways as Sadataka, together with his older brother Nagafusa, opposed to the Retired Emperor Gotoba raising an army in the occasion of Jokyu War.

sen.j: 九条道家から信頼が厚く、特に承久の乱後にはその政治顧問の最上位を占めて平経高らと道家を支える。
sen.e: He was deeply trusted by Michiie KUJO, and particularly after the Jokyu War, he was appointed higher ranks supporting Michiie as his political adviser, along with TAIRA no Tsunetaka and others.
He was deeply trusted by Michiie KUJO, and particularly after the Jokyu War, he was appointed higher ranks supporting Michiie as his political adviser, along with TAIRA no Tsunetaka and others.
He was deeply trusted by Michiie KUJO, and particularly after the Jokyu War, he was appointed higher ranks supporting Michiie as his political adviser, along with TAIRA no Tsunetaka and others.

sen.j: 特に承久の変での経緯から鎌倉幕府からは好意的に見られ、関東申次であった道家の下で実際の幕府との交渉を行っていたのは全て定高であったとされている。
sen.e: He was favored by the Kamakura bakufu especially because of his stance he had taken during the Jokyu War, and it is believed that actual negotiations with the bakufu was exclusively handled by Sadataka, reporting to Michiie, who was Kanto moshitsugi (court-appointed liaison with the bakufu).

He was favored by the Kamakura bakufu especially because of his stance he had taken during the Jokyu War, and it is believed that actual negotiations with the bakufu was exclusively handled by Sadataka working under the Kanto moshitsugi (court-appointed liaison with the bakufu), Michiie.
sen.cmt: 「関東申次出会った道家の下で〜」の部分が意訳され意味が加えられていましたので、簡略化し、原文に沿ったものとしました。
sen.e: He was favored by the Kamakura bakufu especially because of his stance he had taken during the Jokyu War, and it is believed that actual negotiations with the bakufu was exclusively handled by Sadataka working under the Kanto moshitsugi (court-appointed liaison with the bakufu), Michiie.

sen.j: また、斎宮であった後鳥羽上皇の皇女煕子内親王を深草の別邸で引き取ったことでも知られている。
sen.e: He was also famous for having taken in Imperial Princess Kishi (Hiroko), a daugther of the Retired Emperor Gotoba who was a Saigu (Imperial Princesses serving at the Ise-jingu Shrine), to his villa in Fukakusa.
sen.cmt: 「煕子」の読み方は定かではありません。一般的には「きし」と「ひろこ」のどちらとも読めるようです。"Kishi (Hiroko)"としました。Saigu の説明は、C列の説明を流用しました。 (用語集には別の説明もありました。）
sen.e: He was also known for having taken in Imperial Princess Kishi (Hiroko), a daughter of the Retired Emperor Gotoba and a Saigu (Imperial Princesses serving at the Ise-jingu Shrine), to his villa in Fukakusa.
sen.cmt: 原文、「知られている」を「famous for」とするのは強すぎると思いましたので、「known for」としました。「a daugther of the Retired Emperor Gotoba who was a Saigu」の訳ですが、この場合「斎宮であった後鳥羽上皇の娘」となり、「斎宮であった煕子内親王」の誤訳になります。修正しました。
sen.e: He was also known for having taken in Imperial Princess Kishi (Hiroko), a daughter of the Retired Emperor Gotoba and a Saigu (Imperial Princesses serving at the Ise-jingu Shrine), to his villa in Fukakusa.

sen.j: 貞永元年（1232年）に正二位に昇るが権中納言を辞任、嘉禎2年（1236年）に按察使に任ぜられる。
sen.e: In 1232, he was promoted to Shonii (Senior Second Rank) but resigned from Gon Chunagon, and was appointed to Azechi (inspector of the provincial government) in 1236.
In 1232, he was promoted to Shonii (Senior Second Rank) but he resigned from Gon Chunagon; then he was appointed to Azechi (inspector of the provincial government) in 1236.
sen.cmt: 「he was〜but resigned」の訳ですが、butに続く分節の文頭から主語heを削除しているのは文構成が異なるため、あまり好ましくないと思います。「he」を加え、butに続く文が独立して成立するようにしました。新たな任については前の文より分割し（「；」を用いました）はっきり区切りました。
sen.e: In 1232, he was promoted to Shonii (Senior Second Rank) but he resigned from Gon Chunagon; then he was appointed to Azechi (inspector of the provincial government) in 1236.

sen.j: 暦仁元年（1238年）の病のために出家、間もなく没した。
sen.e: In 1238, he entered into priesthood as he suffered from a disease, and died shortly after.
In 1238, he entered into priesthood as he suffered from a disease, and died shortly after.
